member.name: T:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskService
member.summary: Provides access to the Task Scheduler service for managing registered tasks.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskService.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new instance of a TaskService connecting to the local machine as the current user.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskService.#ctor(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The name of the computer that you want to connect to. If the this parameter is empty, then this will connect to the local computer.
The user name that is used during the connection to the computer. If the user is not specified, then the current token is used.
The domain of the user specified in the parameter.
The password that is used to connect to the computer. If the user name and password are not specified, then the current token is used.
If set to true force Task Scheduler 1.0 compatibility.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskService.AddTask(System.String,Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.Trigger,Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.Action,System.String,System.String,Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskLogonType)
member.summary: Creates a new task, registers the taks, and returns the instance.
member.param: The task name. If this value is NULL, the task will be registered in the root task folder and the task name will be a GUID value that is created by the Task Scheduler service. A task name cannot begin or end with a space character. The '.' character cannot be used to specify the current task folder and the '..' characters cannot be used to specify the parent task folder in the path.
The to determine when to run the task.
The to determine what happens when the task is triggered.
The user credentials used to register the task.
The password for the userId used to register the task.
A value that defines what logon technique is used to run the registered task.
member.returns: A instance of the registered task.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskService.FindTask(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Finds a task given a name and standard wildcards.
member.param: The task name. This can include the wildcards * or ?.
if set to true search all sub folders.
member.returns: A if one matches , otherwise NULL.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskService.GetFolder(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the path to a folder of registered tasks.
member.param: The path to the folder to retrieve. Do not use a backslash following the last folder name in the path. The root task folder is specified with a backslash (\). An example of a task folder path, under the root task folder, is \MyTaskFolder. The '.' character cannot be used to specify the current task folder and the '..' characters cannot be used to specify the parent task folder in the path.
member.returns: instance for the requested folder.
member.exception: Folder other than the root (\) was requested on a system not supporting Task Scheduler 2.0.

member.returns: instance with the list of running tasks.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskCompatibility
member.summary: Defines what versions of Task Scheduler or the AT command that the task is compatible with.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskCompatibility.AT
member.summary: The task is compatible with the AT command.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskCompatibility.V1
member.summary: The task is compatible with Task Scheduler 1.0.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskCompatibility.V2
member.summary: The task is compatible with Task Scheduler 2.0.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskCreation
member.summary: Defines how the Task Scheduler service creates, updates, or disables the task.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskCreation.Create
member.summary: The Task Scheduler service registers the task as a new task.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskCreation.CreateOrUpdate
member.summary: The Task Scheduler service either registers the task as a new task or as an updated version if the task already exists. Equivalent to Create | Update.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskCreation.Disable
member.summary: The Task Scheduler service registers the disabled task. A disabled task cannot run until it is enabled. For more information, see Enabled Property of TaskSettings and Enabled Property of RegisteredTask.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskCreation.DontAddPrincipalAce
member.summary: The Task Scheduler service is prevented from adding the allow access-control entry (ACE) for the context principal. When the TaskFolder.RegisterTaskDefinition or TaskFolder.RegisterTask functions are called with this flag to update a task, the Task Scheduler service does not add the ACE for the new context principal and does not remove the ACE from the old context principal.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskCreation.IgnoreRegistrationTriggers
member.summary: The Task Scheduler service creates the task, but ignores the registration triggers in the task. By ignoring the registration triggers, the task will not execute when it is registered unless a time-based trigger causes it to execute on registration.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskCreation.Update
member.summary: The Task Scheduler service registers the task as an updated version of an existing task. When a task with a registration trigger is updated, the task will execute after the update occurs.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskCreation.ValidateOnly
member.summary: The Task Scheduler service checks the syntax of the XML that describes the task but does not register the task. This constant cannot be combined with the Create, Update, or CreateOrUpdate values.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskInstancesPolicy
member.summary: Defines how the Task Scheduler handles existing instances of the task when it starts a new instance of the task.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskInstancesPolicy.Parallel
member.summary: Starts new instance while an existing instance is running.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskInstancesPolicy.Queue
member.summary: Starts a new instance of the task after all other instances of the task are complete.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskInstancesPolicy.IgnoreNew
member.summary: Does not start a new instance if an existing instance of the task is running.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskInstancesPolicy.StopExisting
member.summary: Stops an existing instance of the task before it starts a new instance.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskLogonType
member.summary: Defines what logon technique is required to run a task.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskLogonType.None
member.summary: The logon method is not specified. Used for non-NT credentials.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskLogonType.Password
member.summary: Use a password for logging on the user. The password must be supplied at registration time.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskLogonType.S4U
member.summary: Use an existing interactive token to run a task. The user must log on using a service for user (S4U) logon. When an S4U logon is used, no password is stored by the system and there is no access to either the network or to encrypted files.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskLogonType.InteractiveToken
member.summary: User must already be logged on. The task will be run only in an existing interactive session.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskLogonType.Group
member.summary: Group activation. The groupId field specifies the group.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskLogonType.ServiceAccount
member.summary: Indicates that a Local System, Local Service, or Network Service account is being used as a security context to run the task.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskLogonType.InteractiveTokenOrPassword
member.summary: First use the interactive token. If the user is not logged on (no interactive token is available), then the password is used. The password must be specified when a task is registered. This flag is not recommended for new tasks because it is less reliable than Password.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskProcessTokenSidType
member.summary: Defines the types of process security identifier (SID) that can be used by tasks. These changes are used to specify the type of process SID in the IPrincipal2 interface.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskProcessTokenSidType.None
member.summary: No changes will be made to the process token groups list.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskProcessTokenSidType.Unrestricted
member.summary: A task SID that is derived from the task name will be added to the process token groups list, and the token default discretionary access control list (DACL) will be modified to allow only the task SID and local system full control and the account SID read control.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskProcessTokenSidType.Default
member.summary: A Task Scheduler will apply default settings to the task process.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskRunFlags
member.summary: Defines how a task is run.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskRunFlags.AsSelf
member.summary: The task is run as the user who is calling the Run method.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskRunFlags.IgnoreConstraints
member.summary: The task is run regardless of constraints such as "do not run on batteries" or "run only if idle".

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskRunFlags.NoFlags
member.summary: The task is run with all flags ignored.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskRunFlags.UseSessionId
member.summary: The task is run using a terminal server session identifier.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskRunFlags.UserSID
member.summary: The task is run using a security identifier.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskRunLevel
member.summary: Defines LUA elevation flags that specify with what privilege level the task will be run.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskRunLevel.LUA
member.summary: Tasks will be run with the least privileges.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskRunLevel.Highest
member.summary: Tasks will be run with the highest privileges.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskSessionStateChangeType
member.summary: Defines what kind of Terminal Server session state change you can use to trigger a task to start. These changes are used to specify the type of state change in the SessionStateChangeTrigger.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskSessionStateChangeType.ConsoleConnect
member.summary: Terminal Server console connection state change. For example, when you connect to a user session on the local computer by switching users on the computer.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskSessionStateChangeType.ConsoleDisconnect
member.summary: Terminal Server console disconnection state change. For example, when you disconnect to a user session on the local computer by switching users on the computer.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskSessionStateChangeType.RemoteConnect
member.summary: Terminal Server remote connection state change. For example, when a user connects to a user session by using the Remote Desktop Connection program from a remote computer.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskSessionStateChangeType.RemoteDisconnect
member.summary: Terminal Server remote disconnection state change. For example, when a user disconnects from a user session while using the Remote Desktop Connection program from a remote computer.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskSessionStateChangeType.SessionLock
member.summary: Terminal Server session locked state change. For example, this state change causes the task to run when the computer is locked.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskSessionStateChangeType.SessionUnlock
member.summary: Terminal Server session unlocked state change. For example, this state change causes the task to run when the computer is unlocked.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskState
member.summary: Defines the different states that a registered task can be in.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskState.Unknown
member.summary: The state of the task is unknown.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskState.Disabled
member.summary: The task is registered but is disabled and no instances of the task are queued or running. The task cannot be run until it is enabled.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskState.Queued
member.summary: Instances of the task are queued.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskState.Ready
member.summary: The task is ready to be executed, but no instances are queued or running.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskState.Running
member.summary: One or more instances of the task is running.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.IdleSettings
member.summary: Specifies how the Task Scheduler performs tasks when the computer is in an idle condition. For information about idle conditions, see Task Idle Conditions.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.IdleSettings.IdleDuration
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates the amount of time that the computer must be in an idle state before the task is run.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.IdleSettings.RestartOnIdle
member.summary: Gets or sets a Boolean value that indicates whether the task is restarted when the computer cycles into an idle condition more than once.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.IdleSettings.StopOnIdleEnd
member.summary: Gets or sets a Boolean value that indicates that the Task Scheduler will terminate the task if the idle condition ends before the task is completed.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.IdleSettings.WaitTimeout
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates the amount of time that the Task Scheduler will wait for an idle condition to occur.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskSettings
member.summary: Provides the settings that the Task Scheduler service uses to perform the task.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskSettings.Dispose
member.summary: Releases all resources used by this class.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskSettings.AllowDemandStart
member.summary: Gets or sets a Boolean value that indicates that the task can be started by using either the Run command or the Context menu.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskSettings.AllowHardTerminate
member.summary: Gets or sets a Boolean value that indicates that the task may be terminated by using TerminateProcess.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskSettings.Compatibility
member.summary: Gets or sets an integer value that indicates which version of Task Scheduler a task is compatible with.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskSettings.DeleteExpiredTaskAfter
member.summary: Gets or sets the amount of time that the Task Scheduler will wait before deleting the task after it expires.
member.remarks: For Task Scheduler 1.0, this property will return a TimeSpan of 1 second if the task is set to delete when done. For either version, TimeSpan.Zero will indicate that the task should not be deleted.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskSettings.DisallowStartIfOnBatteries
member.summary: Gets or sets a Boolean value that indicates that the task will not be started if the computer is running on battery power.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskSettings.Enabled
member.summary: Gets or sets a Boolean value that indicates that the task is enabled. The task can be performed only when this setting is TRUE.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskSettings.ExecutionTimeLimit
member.summary: Gets or sets the amount of time that is allowed to complete the task.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskSettings.Hidden
member.summary: Gets or sets a Boolean value that indicates that the task will not be visible in the UI by default.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskSettings.IdleSettings
member.summary: Gets or sets the information that specifies how the Task Scheduler performs tasks when the computer is in an idle state.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskSettings.MultipleInstances
member.summary: Gets or sets the policy that defines how the Task Scheduler handles multiple instances of the task.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskSettings.NetworkSettings
member.summary: Gets or sets the network settings object that contains a network profile identifier and name. If the RunOnlyIfNetworkAvailable property of ITaskSettings is true and a network propfile is specified in the NetworkSettings property, then the task will run only if the specified network profile is available.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskSettings.Priority
member.summary: Gets or sets the priority level of the task.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskSettings.RestartCount
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of times that the Task Scheduler will attempt to restart the task.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskSettings.RestartInterval
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that specifies how long the Task Scheduler will attempt to restart the task.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskSettings.RunOnlyIfIdle
member.summary: Gets or sets a Boolean value that indicates that the Task Scheduler will run the task only if the computer is in an idle condition.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskSettings.RunOnlyIfLoggedOn
member.summary: Gets or sets a Boolean value that indicates that the Task Scheduler will run the task only if the user is logged on (v1.0 only)

member.name: P:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskSettings.RunOnlyIfNetworkAvailable
member.summary: Gets or sets a Boolean value that indicates that the Task Scheduler will run the task only when a network is available.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskSettings.StartWhenAvailable
member.summary: Gets or sets a Boolean value that indicates that the Task Scheduler can start the task at any time after its scheduled time has passed.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskSettings.StopIfGoingOnBatteries
member.summary: Gets or sets a Boolean value that indicates that the task will be stopped if the computer switches to battery power.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskSettings.WakeToRun
member.summary: Gets or sets a Boolean value that indicates that the Task Scheduler will wake the computer when it is time to run the task.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskSettings.XmlText
member.summary: Gets or sets an XML-formatted definition of the task settings.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskFolder
member.summary: Provides the methods that are used to register (create) tasks in the folder, remove tasks from the folder, and create or remove subfolders from the folder.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskFolder.Dispose
member.summary: Releases all resources used by this class.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskFolder.CreateFolder(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a folder for related tasks. Not available to Task Scheduler 1.0.
member.param: The name used to identify the folder. If "FolderName\SubFolder1\SubFolder2" is specified, the entire folder tree will be created if the folders do not exist. This parameter can be a relative path to the current instance. The root task folder is specified with a backslash (\). An example of a task folder path, under the root task folder, is \MyTaskFolder. The '.' character cannot be used to specify the current task folder and the '..' characters cannot be used to specify the parent task folder in the path.
member.returns: A instance that represents the new subfolder.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskFolder.CreateFolder(System.String,System.Security.AccessControl.GenericSecurityDescriptor)
member.summary: Creates a folder for related tasks. Not available to Task Scheduler 1.0.
member.param: The name used to identify the folder. If "FolderName\SubFolder1\SubFolder2" is specified, the entire folder tree will be created if the folders do not exist. This parameter can be a relative path to the current instance. The root task folder is specified with a backslash (\). An example of a task folder path, under the root task folder, is \MyTaskFolder. The '.' character cannot be used to specify the current task folder and the '..' characters cannot be used to specify the parent task folder in the path.
The security descriptor associated with the folder.
member.returns: A instance that represents the new subfolder.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskFolder.CreateFolder(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Creates a folder for related tasks. Not available to Task Scheduler 1.0.
member.param: The name used to identify the folder. If "FolderName\SubFolder1\SubFolder2" is specified, the entire folder tree will be created if the folders do not exist. This parameter can be a relative path to the current instance. The root task folder is specified with a backslash (\). An example of a task folder path, under the root task folder, is \MyTaskFolder. The '.' character cannot be used to specify the current task folder and the '..' characters cannot be used to specify the parent task folder in the path.
The security descriptor associated with the folder.
member.returns: A instance that represents the new subfolder.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskFolder.DeleteFolder(System.String)
member.summary: Deletes a subfolder from the parent folder. Not available to Task Scheduler 1.0.
member.param: The name of the subfolder to be removed. The root task folder is specified with a backslash (\). This parameter can be a relative path to the folder you want to delete. An example of a task folder path, under the root task folder, is \MyTaskFolder. The '.' character cannot be used to specify the current task folder and the '..' characters cannot be used to specify the parent task folder in the path.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskFolder.GetTasks(System.Text.RegularExpressions.Regex)
member.summary: Gets a collection of all the tasks in the folder whose name matches the optional .
member.param: The optional name filter expression.
member.returns: Collection of all matching tasks.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskFolder.DeleteTask(System.String)
member.summary: Deletes a task from the folder.
member.param: The name of the task that is specified when the task was registered. The '.' character cannot be used to specify the current task folder and the '..' characters cannot be used to specify the parent task folder in the path.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskFolder.RegisterTask(System.String,System.String,Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskCreation,System.String,System.String,Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskLogonType,System.String)
member.summary: Registers (creates) a new task in the folder using XML to define the task. Not available for Task Scheduler 1.0.
member.param: The task name. If this value is NULL, the task will be registered in the root task folder and the task name will be a GUID value that is created by the Task Scheduler service. A task name cannot begin or end with a space character. The '.' character cannot be used to specify the current task folder and the '..' characters cannot be used to specify the parent task folder in the path.
An XML-formatted definition of the task.
A union of flags.
The user credentials used to register the task.
The password for the userId used to register the task.
A value that defines what logon technique is used to run the registered task.

The security descriptor associated with the registered task. You can specify the access control list (ACL) in the security descriptor for a task in order to allow or deny certain users and groups access to a task.
member.returns: A instance that represents the new task.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskFolder.RegisterTaskDefinition(System.String,Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.TaskDefinition)
member.summary: Registers (creates) a task in a specified location using a instance to define a task.
member.param: The task name. If this value is NULL, the task will be registered in the root task folder and the task name will be a GUID value that is created by the Task Scheduler service. A task name cannot begin or end with a space character. The '.' character cannot be used to specify the current task folder and the '..' characters cannot be used to specify the parent task folder in the path.
The of the registered task.
member.returns: A instance that represents the new task.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.ITaskHandler
member.summary: Defines the methods that are called by the Task Scheduler service to manage a COM handler.
member.remarks: This interface must be implemented for a task to perform a COM handler action. When the Task Scheduler performs a COM handler action, it creates and activates the handler and calls the methods of this interface as needed. For information on specifying a COM handler action, see the class.

member.summary: Called to start the COM handler. This method must be implemented by the handler.

The arguments that are required by the handler. These arguments are defined in the property of the COM handler action.

member.summary: Called to stop the COM handler. This method must be implemented by the handler.
member.param: The return code that the Task Schedule will raise as an event when the COM handler action is completed.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.V1Interop.TaskFlags
member.summary: Options for a task, used for the Flags property of a Task. Uses the "Flags" attribute, so these values are combined with |. Some flags are documented as Windows 95 only, but they have a user interface in Windows XP so that may not be true.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.V1Interop.TaskFlags.Interactive
member.summary: The interactive flag is set if the task is intended to be displayed to the user. If the flag is not set, no user interface associated with the task is presented to the user when the task is executed.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.V1Interop.TaskFlags.DeleteWhenDone
member.summary: The task will be deleted when there are no more scheduled run times.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.V1Interop.TaskFlags.Disabled
member.summary: The task is disabled. This is useful to temporarily prevent a task from running at the scheduled time(s).

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.V1Interop.TaskFlags.StartOnlyIfIdle
member.summary: The task begins only if the computer is not in use at the scheduled start time. Windows 95 only.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.V1Interop.TaskFlags.KillOnIdleEnd
member.summary: The task terminates if the computer makes an idle to non-idle transition while the task is running. The computer is not considered idle until the IdleWait triggers' time elapses with no user input. Windows 95 only. For information regarding idle triggers, see .

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.V1Interop.TaskFlags.DontStartIfOnBatteries
member.summary: The task does not start if its target computer is running on battery power. Windows 95 only.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.V1Interop.TaskFlags.KillIfGoingOnBatteries
member.summary: The task ends, and the associated application quits if the task's target computer switches to battery power. Windows 95 only.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.V1Interop.TaskFlags.RunOnlyIfDocked
member.summary: The task runs only if the system is docked. Windows 95 only.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.V1Interop.TaskFlags.Hidden
member.summary: The task is hidden. When the task begins execution, it runs in a hidden window.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.V1Interop.TaskFlags.RunIfConnectedToInternet
member.summary: The task runs only if there is currently a valid Internet connection. This feature is currently not implemented.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.V1Interop.TaskFlags.RestartOnIdleResume
member.summary: The task starts again if the computer makes a non-idle to idle transition before all the task's task_triggers elapse. (Use this flag in conjunction with KillOnIdleEnd.) Windows 95 only.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.V1Interop.TaskFlags.SystemRequired
member.summary: The task runs only if the SYSTEM account is available.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.V1Interop.TaskFlags.RunOnlyIfLoggedOn
member.summary: The task runs only if the user specified in SetAccountInformation is logged on interactively. This flag has no effect on work items set to run in the local account.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.V1Interop.TaskStatus
member.summary: Status values returned for a task. Some values have been determined to occur although they do no appear in the Task Scheduler system documentation.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.V1Interop.TaskStatus.Ready
member.summary: The task is ready to run at its next scheduled time.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.V1Interop.TaskStatus.Running
member.summary: The task is currently running.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.V1Interop.TaskStatus.NotScheduled
member.summary: One or more of the properties that are needed to run this task on a schedule have not been set.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.V1Interop.TaskStatus.NeverRun
member.summary: The task has not yet run.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.V1Interop.TaskStatus.Disabled
member.summary: The task will not run at the scheduled times because it has been disabled.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.V1Interop.TaskStatus.NoMoreRuns
member.summary: There are no more runs scheduled for this task.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.V1Interop.TaskStatus.Terminated
member.summary: The last run of the task was terminated by the user.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.V1Interop.TaskStatus.NoTriggers
member.summary: Either the task has no triggers or the existing triggers are disabled or not set.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.V1Interop.TaskStatus.NoTriggerTime
member.summary: Event triggers don't have set run times.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.V1Interop.TaskTriggerType
member.summary: Valid types of triggers

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.V1Interop.TaskTriggerType.RunOnce
member.summary: Trigger is set to run the task a single time.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.V1Interop.TaskTriggerType.RunDaily
member.summary: Trigger is set to run the task on a daily interval.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.V1Interop.TaskTriggerType.RunWeekly
member.summary: Trigger is set to run the work item on specific days of a specific week of a specific month.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.V1Interop.TaskTriggerType.RunMonthly
member.summary: Trigger is set to run the task on a specific day(s) of the month.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.V1Interop.TaskTriggerType.RunMonthlyDOW
member.summary: Trigger is set to run the task on specific days, weeks, and months.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.V1Interop.TaskTriggerType.OnIdle
member.summary: Trigger is set to run the task if the system remains idle for the amount of time specified by the idle wait time of the task.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.V1Interop.TaskTriggerType.OnSystemStart
member.summary: Trigger is set to run the task at system startup.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.V1Interop.TaskTriggerType.OnLogon
member.summary: Trigger is set to run the task when a user logs on.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.DaysOfTheWeek
member.summary: Values for days of the week (Monday, Tuesday, etc.)

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.DaysOfTheWeek.Sunday
member.summary: Sunday

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.DaysOfTheWeek.Monday

member.name: T:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.LogonTrigger
member.summary: Represents a trigger that starts a task when a user logs on. When the Task Scheduler service starts, all logged-on users are enumerated and any tasks registered with logon triggers that match the logged on user are run. Not available on Task Scheduler 1.0.

member.summary: Creates an unbound instance of a .

member.returns: String describing the trigger.

member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates the amount of time between when the system is booted and when the task is started.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Win32.TaskScheduler.LogonTrigger.UserId

summary.para: Gets or sets The identifier of the user. For example, "MyDomain\MyName" or for a local account, "Administrator".
This property can be in one of the following formats:
User name or SID: The task is started when the user logs on to the computer.
NULL: The task is started when any user logs on to the computer.

member.remarks: If you want a task to be triggered when any member of a group logs on to the computer rather than when a specific user logs on, then do not assign a value to the LogonTrigger.UserId property. Instead, create a logon trigger with an empty LogonTrigger.UserId property and assign a value to the principal for the task using the Principal.GroupId property.

member.returns: An array with an element for each bit of the mask which is ON.
